== Calculation ==
  +
To calculate the amount of sunlight reaching the ground, both the [[Ellipse|elliptical]] [[Earth's orbit|orbit]] of the [[Earth]] and the [[Extinction (astronomy)#Atmospheric extinction|attenuation]] by the [[Earth's atmosphere]] have to be taken into account. The extraterrestrial solar illuminance (''E''<sub>ext</sub>), corrected for the elliptical orbit by using the day number of the year (dn), is given by
  +
:<math>E_{\rm ext}= E_{\rm sc} \cdot (1+0.033412 \cdot \cos\left(2\pi\frac{{\rm dn}-3}{365}\right)),</math>
  +
where dn=1 on January 1; dn=2 on January 2; dn=32 on February 1, etc. In this formula dn-3 is used, because in modern times [[Apsis#Earth's perihelion and aphelion|Earth's perihelion]], the closest approach to the [[Sun]] and therefore the maximum ''E''<sub>ext</sub> occurs around January 3 each year. The value of .033412 is determined knowing that the ratio between the perihelion (0.98328989 AU) squared and the aphelion (1.01671033 AU) squared should be approximately 0.935338.
  +   +
The solar illuminance constant (''E''<sub>sc</sub>), is equal to 128Ã10<sup>3</sup> [[Lux|lx]]. The direct normal illuminance (''E''<sub>dn</sub>), corrected for the attenuating effects of the atmosphere is given by:
  +
:<math>E_{\rm dn}=E_{\rm ext}\,e^{-cm},</math>
  +   +
where ''c'' is the atmospheric [[refractive index#Dispersion and absorption|extinction coefficient]] and ''m'' is the relative optical [[airmass]].
